questions.text: While otoscopy, the patient started coughing. Stimulations of which nerve leads to cough?
questions.solution:
Arnold's nerve, also known as the auricular branch of the vagus nerve (CN X), supplies sensory innervation to the external acoustic meatus. Stimulation of Arnold's nerve can lead to a cough reflex as the vagus nerve is involved in the regulation of the respiratory system and can initiate a cough response to protect the airway.

Other options:

  • Jacobson's nerve:This is a tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve that supplies sensation to the posterior tongue and the tonsils. It also supplies middle ear .It doesn't causes cough reflex.
  • Nerve of Wrisberg:It is also known as the intermediate nerve, is a branch of the facial nerve (CN VII). It supplies skin of the posterior superior part of external auditory canal.It contains sensory and parasympathetic fibers that supply the tympanic membrane. The nerve of Wrisberg arises from the facial nerve in the geniculate ganglion. The tympanic branch supplies sensory innervation to the tympanic membrane and the middle ear. The lesser petrosal nerve supplies parasympathetic innervation to the parotid gland.
  • Vidian nerve:This is a branch of the trigeminal nerve that supplies sensation to the pterygopalatine fossa. It does not supply sensation to the middle ear, so it would not cause a cough reflex when the eardrum is stimulated.

KEY TAKEAWAY- Syncopal effect during syringing is due to Arnold's nerve stimulation. Vagus is a parasympathetic nerve and stimulation of it gives rise to hypotension and bradycardia.

questions.text: Steeple sign on X-ray neck AP view is seen in?
questions.solution:
The "steeple sign" on an X-ray of the neck (AP view) is indicative of acute laryngotracheobronchitis, commonly known as croup. Croup is characterized by inflammation of the upper airway, specifically the larynx and trachea, leading to narrowing of the subglottic region and causing the characteristic steeple-like appearance on X-ray.

Other options:

A. Acute epiglottitis: Acute epiglottitis causes inflammation and swelling of the epiglottis, which leads to a "thumbprint sign" on X-ray, not the steeple sign.

C. Laryngomalacia: Laryngomalacia is a congenital condition where the soft tissues of the larynx collapse during inspiration, causing a characteristic "omega-shaped" epiglottis on X-ray, not the steeple sign.

D. Laryngeal web: A laryngeal web is a congenital condition where there is a membrane or web-like structure across the larynx, which may cause respiratory difficulty, but it does not result in the steeple sign on X-ray.

questions.text: Saccule of inner ear develop from
questions.solution:
During embryonic development, the saccule, one of the two otolith organs in the inner ear, develops from the pars inferior to the otocyst. The saccule is responsible for detecting linear acceleration and head position.

Other options:

  • Sacculus anteriorThis is a small sac that is located in the utricle of the inner ear. It is not involved in the development of the saccule.
  • Pars superior:This is the superior portion of the otic vesicle. It gives rise to the utricle and the semicircular canals.

questions.text: Partial closure of nasal orifice done in which condition?
questions.solution:
Partial closure of the nasal orifice is performed in cases of atrophic rhinitis. Atrophic rhinitis is a condition characterized by the thinning and wasting away of the nasal mucosa, leading to crusting, dryness, and foul-smelling nasal discharge. Partial closure aims to improve symptoms and airflow through the nose.

MODIFIED YOUNG'S OPERATION- done for atrophic rhinitis.


Other options:

  • Chronic fungal aspergillosis:This is a chronic infection of the nose and sinuses caused by the fungus Aspergillus. It can cause nasal obstruction, but it is not typically associated with partial closure of the nasal orifices.
  • Vasomotor rhinitis:This is a condition in which the blood vessels in the nose become dilated, causing congestion. It can cause nasal obstruction, but it is not typically associated with partial closure of the nasal orifices.
  • Fungal mucormycosis:This is a serious infection of the nose and sinuses caused by the fungus Mucor. It can cause nasal obstruction, but it is not typically associated with partial closure of the nasal orifices.

questions.text: Not a surgical landmark for parotid surgery?
questions.solution:
Justification:


The inferior belly of the omohyoid muscle is not a surgical landmark specifically used in parotid surgery. Parotid surgery typically involves identifying and preserving the facial nerve (CN VII) as it passes through the parotid gland. Several other structures serve as important surgical landmarks during parotid surgery.

Other options:

These are used to locate facial nerves.

B. Tragal pointer: The nerve lies 1 cm deep and slightly anterior and inferior triangular to the pointer. A cartilaginous pointer is a sharp triangular piece of cartilage of the pinna and points to the nerve.

C. Digastric posterior belly: If the posterior belly of digastric is traced backwards along its upper border to its attachment to the digastric groove nerve is found to lie between it and the styloid process.

D. Tympanomastoid suture:Nerve lies 6 to 8 mm deep to this suture.

questions.text: A patient with a history of road traffic accident and had a fracture in middle cranial fossa. What is the name of the clinical sign shown in the picture?
questions.solution:
The clinical sign shown in the picture is called the Battle sign. It refers to the presence of ecchymosis (bruising) behind the ear and is associated with fractures involving the middle cranial fossa. The ecchymosis occurs due to the leakage of blood into the soft tissues around the mastoid process and is considered a sign of basilar skull fracture.

Other options:

  • Bryce sign:This is a bluish discoloration that is seen in the mastoid region in patients with a fracture of the temporal bone. It is not typically seen behind the ear.
  • Waters sign:This is a finding on X-ray neck AP view that is seen in patients with a fracture of the maxilla. It is not typically seen behind the ear.
  • Griesinger sign:This is a finding on X-ray neck AP view that is seen in patients with a fracture of the mandible. It is not typically seen behind the ear.

questions.text: Surgical procedure which involves reconstruction of cartilaginous part of the external auditory canal?
questions.solution:
Meatoplasty is a surgical procedure that involves the reconstruction or enlargement of the cartilaginous part of the external auditory canal. It is performed to improve access, drainage, and ventilation of the ear canal.It is the last step of modified radical mastoidectomy.

Other options:

A. Canaloplasty: Canaloplasty is a surgical procedure used to treat glaucoma by enlarging and restructuring the eye's drainage canal.

B. Myringoplasty: Myringoplasty is a surgical procedure to repair a perforated tympanic membrane (eardrum), not involving the cartilaginous part of the external auditory canal.

C. Tympanoplasty: Tympanoplasty is a surgical procedure to repair or reconstruct the middle ear, including the tympanic membrane and ossicles, but not specifically the cartilaginous part of the external auditory canal.

questions.text: A patient presented with fever, plummy voice and difficulty in swallowing. The oropharyngeal picture is shown in the image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
uvula is pushed to the other side and tonsil is pushed medially.It is a typical finding in peritonsillar abscess also known as quincy.

The oropharyngeal picture shown indicates the presence of a peritonsillar abscess. A peritonsillar abscess is a collection of pus located between the tonsillar capsule and the superior constrictor muscle. It can cause symptoms such as fever, severe sore throat, "hot potato" voice (muffled voice), and difficulty swallowing.

Other options:

B. Parapharyngeal abscess: A parapharyngeal abscess is a deep neck infection involving the spaces around the pharynx, and it would not typically present with the specific oropharyngeal appearance seen in the image.It presents with neck swelling or swelling near the angle of mouth

C. Retropharyngeal abscess: A retropharyngeal abscess is an infection located in the retropharyngeal space, but it would not produce the distinct bulging seen in the tonsillar area in the image.It produces swelling in the posterior pharyngeal wall.

D. Ludwig's angina: Ludwig's angina is a severe infection involving the submandibular, sublingual, and submental spaces of the neck, which can cause significant swelling and elevation of the tongue, but it would not present with a peritonsillar appearance as seen in the image.

questions.text: Tubercular otitis media is characterized by all except
questions.solution:
Tubercular otitis media is characterized by multiple perforations in the tympanic membrane, pale granulations, and foul-smelling ear discharge. Painful otorrhea is not a typical feature of tubercular otitis media.

In laryngeal Tb there will be painful phonation.

Other options and why they are wrong:

B. Multiple perforations: Multiple perforations in the tympanic membrane are a characteristic feature of tubercular otitis media due to the destructive nature of the disease.

C. Pale granulations: Tubercular otitis media is associated with pale or edematous granulations due to the chronic inflammatory process.

D. Foul-smelling ear discharge: Foul-smelling or purulent ear discharge is commonly observed in tubercular otitis media due to the chronic infection.

questions.text: Occipitomental view with open mouth view to check for nose and paranasal sinus?
questions.solution:
The Occipitomental view with an open mouth view is commonly known as the "Pierre view." This imaging technique is used to visualize the nose and paranasal sinuses and is particularly useful in assessing the maxillary sinuses and the nasal bones.


Other options:

B.Waters view: The Waters view is a radiographic view used to visualize the maxillary sinuses and their relationship to the orbital floor. It does not require the open mouth position.

C.Caldwell view: The Caldwell view is an X-ray projection used to evaluate the frontal sinuses and their relationship to the orbits. It is taken with the patient's head tilted backward but does not involve an open mouth view.


D.Townes view: The Townes view, also known as the "jug-handle" view, is used for imaging the skull base, including the sella turcica. It is not used to check the nose and paranasal sinuses. It helps to visualize foramen magnum, petrous temporal bone
